events.description: Bitcoin dropped toward $62,000 in early February, reaching its lowest level in 17 months.
A wide-scale selloff across various financial markets affecting multiple asset classes.

facts.fact_text: Bitcoin reached its lowest price levels since October 2024 in early February.

evidences.evidence_text: hitting its lowest levels since October 2024 as the market continued to flush out leveraged traders

facts.fact_text: Bitcoin has lost approximately 50% of its value since its peak in October 2025.

evidences.evidence_text: The leading cryptocurrency has now lost about half its value from its October 2025 peak

facts.fact_text: The decline in Bitcoin impacted related ETFs and companies like Strategy Inc.

evidences.evidence_text: The selloff has also spread to other cryptocurrencies, related ETFs and companies that hold massive bitcoin holdings such as Strategy Inc.

claims.claim_text: The market is currently flushing out leveraged traders.

evidences.evidence_text: as the market continued to flush out leveraged traders amid a broad selloff across financial markets

claims.claim_text: Bitcoin has failed to act as a hedge against currency debasement compared to gold.
claims.author: Some analysts

evidences.evidence_text: failing to function as a debasement hedge comparable to gold and other precious metals

claims.claim_text: Bitcoin is primarily a speculative asset rather than a utility-driven one.
claims.author: Some analysts

evidences.evidence_text: Some analysts argue that bitcoin has been exposed as a largely speculative asset

evidence.evidence_text: Bitcoin plunged toward $62,000 in early February... amid a broad selloff across financial markets.
Investor optimism had previously been buoyed by Trump’s direct involvement in the sector and his pledges to ease regulation
The selloff has also spread to other cryptocurrencies, related ETFs and companies that hold massive bitcoin holdings such as Strategy Inc.
Some analysts argue that bitcoin has been exposed as a largely speculative asset
